translated: The Buddha Speaks the MahÄyÄna Rice Seedling SÅ«tra
Thus have I heard. Once, the Blessed One was dwelling in RÄjagá¹›ha on Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a Mountain,
together with a great assembly of 1,250 bhiká¹£us, and with bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas
all together.

At that time, the Venerable ÅšÄriputra went to the place where the Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva Maitreya was practicing walking meditation. When he arrived, they exchanged greetings and sat together on a flat rock.
At that time, the Venerable ÅšÄriputra said to the Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva Maitreya,
Maitreya!
Today the World-Honored One saw rice seedlings and told the bhiká¹£us, saying:
'Bhiká¹£us!
If one sees causes and conditions, one then sees the Dharma;
if one sees the Dharma, one is then able to see the Buddha.'
Having said this, he fell silent.
Maitreya!
Why did the Well-Gone One speak like this?ğŸ”½What is the matter?
What are causes and conditions?
What is the Dharma?
What is the Buddha?
How can seeing dependent origination be the same as seeing the Dharma?
How can seeing the Dharma be the same as seeing the Buddha?
Having said this, Maitreya Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva replied to the Venerable ÅšÄriputra, saying:
Now the Buddha, the Dharma King, the Perfectly Enlightened One, tells the bhiká¹£us:
'If one sees dependent origination, one can see the Dharma;
if one sees the Dharma, one can see the Buddha.'
What is meant by dependent origination here?
As for dependent origination, it means this exists because that exists, this arises because that arises.

Namely, ignorance conditions formations, formations condition consciousness, consciousness conditions name-and-form, name-and-form conditions the six sense bases, the six sense bases condition contact, contact conditions feeling, feeling conditions craving, craving conditions clinging, clinging conditions becoming, becoming conditions birth, birth conditions old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, dejection, and mental anguish arise;
In this way, only the mass of extremely great suffering arises.

Here, due to the cessation of ignorance, formations cease; due to the cessation of formations, consciousness ceases; due to the cessation of consciousness, name-and-form ceases; due to the cessation of name-and-form, the six sense bases cease; due to the cessation of the six sense bases, contact ceases; due to the cessation of contact, feeling ceases; due to the cessation of feeling, craving ceases; due to the cessation of craving, clinging ceases; due to the cessation of clinging, existence ceases; due to the cessation of existence, birth ceases; due to the cessation of birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, dejection, and distress cease;
in this way, only the mass of extremely great suffering ceases.
This is the dependent origination taught by the World-Honored One.
What is the Dharma?
It refers to the eightfold noble path:
right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.
This is the eightfold noble path, its fruits, and nirvana.
What is taught by the World-Honored One is called the Dharma.
What is the Buddha?
It is said that one who knows all dharmas is called a Buddha, because with the eye of wisdom and the Dharma body one can see and accomplish the dharmas of enlightenment, learning, and no-learning.
How does one see dependent origination?

As the Buddha said, if one can see the dharmas of dependent origination as permanent, without life, apart from life, with the nature of suchness, the nature of non-error, unborn, unarisen, uncreated, unconditioned, unobstructed, without objects, tranquil, fearless, unassailable, and with the characteristic of non-tranquility, then one can see the Buddha with the unsurpassed Dharma body through correct wisdom and realize the supreme Dharma.
It was asked:ğŸ”½What is the meaning of 'permanent'?
Why is it called dependent origination?
He replied:
Because there are causes and conditions, it is called dependent origination. It is not without causes and conditions, therefore it is called the Dharma of dependent origination.
The World-Honored One briefly explained the characteristics of dependent origination, and the fruits that arise from those conditions.

Whether the TathÄgata appears or does not appear, the nature of dharmas always abides, up to the nature of the Dharma, the nature of the abiding of the Dharma, the nature of the determination of the Dharma, the nature of being in accord with causes and conditions, the nature of suchness, the nature of being non-erroneous, the nature of being unchanging, the nature of reality, the nature of the ultimate truth, the nature of non-delusion, the nature of non-inversion, and so forth, are explained in this way.
This Dharma of dependent origination arises through two kinds.
What are the two?
Namely, being in accord with causes and being in accord with conditions.
They are further divided into two, namely external and internal.
What among these is the Dharma of external causes and conditions being in accord with causes?
Namely, from seeds sprouts grow, from sprouts leaves grow, from leaves stems grow, from stems nodes grow, from nodes tassels grow, from tassels flowers grow, and from flowers fruits grow.
If there are no seeds, sprouts will not grow;
up to if there are no flowers, fruits will also not grow.
When there are seeds, sprouts grow;
likewise, when there are flowers, fruits can also grow.
That seed also does not think:
'I can produce a sprout.'
The sprout also does not think:
'I am produced from a seed.'
Up to the flower also does not think:
'I can produce a fruit.'
The fruit also does not think:
'I am produced from a flower.'
Nevertheless, because there are seeds, sprouts can grow;
likewise, because there are flowers, fruits can be accomplished.
One should contemplate the meaning of the principle of causes in the external dependent origination in this way.
How should one contemplate the meaning of the conditioned arising of external dependent origination?
It means that because of the combination of the six elements,
by what six elements are they combined?
Namely, the combination of the earth, water, fire, wind, space, and time elements, external dependent origination can arise.
One should contemplate the meaning of the conditioned arising of external dependent origination in this way.ğŸ”½As for the earth element, it can support the seeds.
As for the water element, it can moisten the seeds.ğŸ”½As for the fire element, it can warm the seeds.
As for the wind element, it can move the seeds.
As for the space element, it does not obstruct the seeds.
Time can transform the seeds.
If these conditions are absent, the seeds cannot give rise to sprouts.

If the external earth element is not incomplete, and likewise, the water, fire, wind, space, and time elements are all not incomplete, all combined, when the seeds cease, sprouts can arise. In this case, the earth element does not think:
'I am able to hold the seeds.'
In the same way, the water element also does not think:
'I am able to moisten the seeds.'
The fire element also does not think:
'I am able to warm the seeds.'
The wind element also does not think:
'I am able to move the seeds.'
The space element also does not think:
'I am able to not obstruct the seeds.'
Time also does not think:
'I am able to change the seeds.'
The seeds also do not think:
'I am able to produce sprouts.'
The sprouts also do not think:
'I now arise from these many conditions.'
Nevertheless, when these many conditions exist, when the seeds perish, the sprouts immediately arise. In the same way, when there are flowers, the fruits immediately arise.
The sprout is not self-made, not made by others, not made by both, not made by ÄªÅ›vara, not transformed by time, not born from self-nature, and not born without a cause.
Nevertheless, when the seed perishes due to the combination of earth, water, fire, wind, space, time, and the elements, the sprout is born.
Therefore, one should contemplate the meaning of the conditioned arising of external dependent origination in this way.
One should contemplate external dependent origination in five ways.
What are the five?
Not permanent, not discontinuous, not transferring, born from a small cause but producing a large effect, and resembling it.
What is meant by not permanent?
Because the sprout is different from the seed.
The sprout is not the seed, and when the seed perishes, the sprout is born;
it is not born without perishing.
When the seed perishes, the sprout is born, therefore it is not permanent.
What is meant by not discontinuous?
It is not that the past seeds perish and give rise to the sprout;
It is also not that without perishing they can give rise to [the sprout].
When the seed perishes, at that time like a scale tipping up and down, the sprout can be born, and therefore it is not cut off.
Why is it not transferred?
The sprout is different from the seed.
Because the sprout is not the seed, therefore it is not transferred.
Why does a small cause give rise to a great result?
From a small seed a great fruit is born, and therefore from a small cause a great result is born.
Why is it similar to that?
Because the fruit is born from the seed that was planted, therefore it is similar to that.
Thus, the five kinds observe the external conditioned factors.
In the same way, the internal conditioned factors are also born in two ways.
What are the two?
Namely, the meaning of being associated with causes and the meaning of being associated with conditions.
What is the meaning of being associated with causes in the internal conditioned factors?
Namely, beginning from ignorance as a condition for volitional actions, up to birth as a condition for old age and death.
If ignorance does not arise, volitional actions will also not exist;
Up to if there is no birth, old age and death will not exist.
Thus, because there is ignorance, volitional actions can arise;
Up to because there is birth, old age and death can exist.
Ignorance also does not think like this:
I can give rise to volitional actions.
Volitional actions also do not think like this:
I arise from ignorance.
Up to birth also does not think like this:
I can give rise to old age and death.
Old age and death also do not think like this:
I exist because of birth.
Nevertheless, because there is ignorance, volitional actions can arise; thus, because there is birth, old age and death can exist.
Therefore, one should contemplate the meaning of the corresponding causes of the internal dependent origination in this way.
How should one contemplate the corresponding events of the internal dependent origination?
It is because of the combination of the six elements.
What are the six elements that combine?
Namely, the combination of the earth, water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements.
One should contemplate the internal dependent origination in this way, in terms of the characteristics of conditions.
What are the characteristics of the earth element in the internal dependent origination?
That which makes the body solid is called the earth element.
That which causes the body to aggregate is called the water element.ğŸ”½That which digests food, drink, mastication, and ingestion in the body is called the fire element.
That which causes the inhalation and exhalation of breath in the body is called the wind element.
That which makes the body hollow is called the space element.

The five groups of consciousnesses, as well as the defiled mental consciousness, like a bundle of reeds, that which can accomplish the sprout of name-and-form of this body is called the consciousness element.
If these many conditions are absent, the body will not arise.
If the internal earth element is not complete, and so on up to the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements, all being incomplete, the body cannot be born due to the combination of all.
That earth element also does not think:
'I can make the body's solid matter.'
The water element also does not think:
'I can gather the body.'
The fire element also does not think:
'I can digest the food, drink, and chewed and swallowed [food] of the body.'
The wind element also does not think:
'I can make the exhalation and inhalation of breath.'
The space element also does not think:
'I can make the empty and unobstructed matter in the body.'
The consciousness element also does not think:
'I can accomplish this body, the sprout of name and form.'
The body also does not think:
'I am born from these many conditions.'
However, when these various conditions are present, the body is able to be born.

That earth element is also not the self, not a sentient being, not a living being, not a life-force, not a person, not an individual, not a man, not a woman, not a eunuch, not a lord, not mine, and also not anything else.

In the same way, the water element, fire element, wind element, space element, and consciousness element are also not the self, not a sentient being, not a living being, not a life-force, not a person, not an individual, not a man, not a woman, not a eunuch, not a lord, not mine, and also not anything else.
What is ignorance?

Regarding these six elements, one gives rise to the notion of oneness, the notion of combination, the notion of permanence, the notion of solidity, the notion of indestructibility, the notion of blissful comfort, the notion of sentient beings, the notion of life, the notion of birth, the notion of nurturing, the notion of human beings, the notion of people, the notion of young men, the notion of the doer, the notion of self, the notion of what belongs to the self, and various other kinds of ignorance. This is ignorance.
Because there is ignorance, one gives rise to craving, ill-will, and delusion regarding sense objects.
Giving rise to craving, ill-will, and delusion regarding sense objects is the condition of ignorance giving rise to karmic formations.
That which is able to cognize various things is called consciousness.
The four appropriated aggregates that arise together with consciousness are called name-and-form.
The faculties based on name-and-form are called the six sense bases.
The coming together of the three factors is called contact.ğŸ”½Experiencing contact is called feeling.ğŸ”½Craving after feeling is called craving.
The increase of craving is called grasping.
The karmic activity that arises from grasping and gives rise to [future] birth is called existence;
The aggregates that are produced from that cause are called birth;ğŸ”½After birth, the maturation of the aggregates is called aging;
After aging, the disintegration of the aggregates is called death;
At the time of death, the internal presence of craving and distress is called sorrow;
The various verbal expressions that arise from sorrow are called lamentation;ğŸ”½The suffering experienced by the five sense consciousnesses is called suffering;
The suffering experienced by the mental consciousness is called distress;
The presence of these and other secondary afflictions is called affliction.
Because it is a great darkness, it is called ignorance;
Because it creates, it is called karmic formations;
Because it cognizes, it is called consciousness;
Because they rely on each other, it is called name-and-form;
Because it serves as the gateway for birth, it is called the six sense bases;ğŸ”½Because of contact, it is called contact;
Because of feeling, it is called feeling;
Thirst is called craving;
Grasping is called grasping;ğŸ”½Causing rebirth is called becoming;
The arising of the aggregates is called birth;
The ripening of the aggregates is called old age;
The disintegration of the aggregates is called death;
Sorrow is called sorrow;
Lamentation is called lamentation;
Afflicting the body is called suffering;
Afflicting the mind is called distress;
Disturbing is called disturbance.
Moreover, not understanding true nature, inverted ignorance is called ignorance.

Thus, because of ignorance, three kinds of actions are formed, namely, meritorious actions, demeritorious actions, and immovable actions.ğŸ”½From meritorious actions arises the consciousness of meritorious actions. This is called ignorance as a condition for action;
From demeritorious actions arises the consciousness of demeritorious actions. This is called action as a condition for consciousness;
From immovable actions arises the consciousness of immovable actions. This is called consciousness as a condition for name-and-form;
Because name-and-form increases, from the six sense doors one is able to accomplish things. This is name-and-form as a condition for the six sense bases;
From the six sense bases, six groups of contact arise. This is the six sense bases as a condition for contact;
From the contacted, one gives rise to feeling. This is called contact as a condition for feeling;
Having discerned feeling, one gives rise to defiled craving and attachment. This is called feeling as a condition for craving;

Because of knowing and giving rise to defiled craving and attachment, one does not wish to be separated from pleasant forms and comfort, and gives rise to aspirations. This is craving as a condition for grasping;
Having given rise to aspirations, one creates karma for future existence through body, speech, and mind. This is grasping as a condition for becoming;
From that karma, the aggregates are produced. This is becoming as a condition for birth;
Having been born, the aggregates mature and perish. This is called birth as a condition for old age and death.

Therefore, these twelve factors of dependent origination mutually serve as causes and conditions for each other. They are neither permanent nor impermanent, neither conditioned nor unconditioned, neither without causes nor without conditions, neither subject to experience nor subject to exhaustion, nor subject to destruction, nor subject to cessation.
From beginningless time, they flow like a great river without interruption.

Nevertheless, these twelve factors of dependent origination mutually serve as causes and conditions for each other. They are neither permanent nor impermanent, neither conditioned nor unconditioned, neither without causes nor without conditions, neither subject to experience nor subject to exhaustion, nor subject to destruction, nor subject to cessation, from beginningless time, they flow like a great river without interruption.
There are four factors that can encompass the twelve factors of dependent origination.
What are the four?
Namely, ignorance, craving, karma, and consciousness.
Consciousness is the cause with the nature of a seed.
As for karma, it is the cause that makes the field nature.
Ignorance and craving are the causes that make the nature of afflictions.

Here, karma and afflictions can give rise to the consciousness that is the seed. Karma can make the consciousness that is the seed the field. Craving can moisten the consciousness that is the seed. Ignorance can plant the consciousness that is the seed.
If these many conditions are absent, the consciousness that is the seed cannot be accomplished.
That karma also does not think:
I now can make the consciousness that is the seed the field.
Craving also does not think:
I now can moisten the consciousness that is the seed.
Ignorance also does not think:
I now can plant the consciousness that is the seed.
That consciousness that is the seed also does not think:
I now arise from these many conditions.

Nevertheless, the consciousness that is the seed, relying on that field of karma and moistened by craving, born from the manure of ignorance, entering the mother's womb, can give rise to the sprout of name-and-form.

That sprout of name-and-form is not self-made, not made by another, not made by both, not created by God, not born from time, not produced by inherent nature, not fashioned by a creator, and not born without a cause.
Although when the parents unite and other conditions come together, the dharma of no-self is without self or possession, just like empty space.

Because those illusory dharmas, causes and conditions are all complete, relying on that place of birth, entering the mother's womb, then one is able to accomplish the consciousness that grasps and holds seeds.
The sprout of name-and-form, like when eye-consciousness arises, if the five conditions are complete, then it can arise.
What are the five?
Namely, the basis, eye, form, light, and space.
Because of the mental activity that relies on the basis, eye-consciousness can arise.
In this, the eye is able to act as the basis for eye-consciousness;
form is able to act as the object of eye-consciousness;
Illumination can manifest things,
emptiness can make things unobstructed,
and attention can think.
If these conditions are absent, eye consciousness does not arise.
If the internal sense of the eye is not complete, and so on, up to form, light, space, and attention not being complete, when all come together, eye consciousness can arise.
The eye also does not think like this:
I now can be the basis for eye consciousness.
Form also does not think:
I now can be the object of eye consciousness.
Light also does not think:
I now can manifest things for eye consciousness.
Space also does not think:
I now can make things unobstructed for eye consciousness.
Attention also does not think:
I now can think for eye consciousness.
That eye consciousness also does not think:
'I arise from these conditions.'
However, with these conditions present, eye consciousness can arise.
This can be applied to the other faculties as well.
Thus, there is no dharma that moves from this world to the next world.
However, when causes and conditions are complete, the results of karma are also manifested.
It is like a mirror reflecting a face.
Although the face does not move into the mirror, when causes and conditions are complete, the reflection of the face appears.
In the same way, nothing moves from this place to another place, but when causes and conditions are complete, the results of karma are also manifested.
It is like the moon, which travels forty-two thousand yojanas from here.
The reflection of the moon appears in a small vessel of water, but the moon does not move from there to the vessel of water.
However, because the causes and conditions are all complete, the moon's orb also appears.
In this way, there is no small part that goes from here to arise elsewhere, because the causes and conditions are all complete, the results of karma also appear.
It is like fire, if the causes and conditions are not complete, it cannot burn;
when the causes and conditions are complete, then it can burn.
In this way, the Dharma of no-self is without self or possession, just like empty space.

Relying on those illusory dharmas, because the causes and conditions are all complete, where one is born, entering the mother's womb, one is then able to accomplish the seeds of consciousness, the sprouts of name-and-form born from karma and afflictions.
Therefore, one should contemplate the internal dependent origination in this way, the corresponding events of conditions.
One should contemplate the internal dependent origination in five ways.
What are the five?
Not permanent, not annihilated, not transferred, producing great fruits from small causes, and resembling them.
How is it not permanent?

It means that the aggregates that cease later and the aggregates that arise are different. Because the aggregates that cease later are not the aggregates that arise, the aggregates that cease later also cease, and the aggregates that arise also appear. Therefore, it is not permanent.
How is it not annihilated?
It is not that when the aggregates that cease later cease, the aggregates that arise exist;
nor is it that without ceasing, the aggregates that cease later also cease. At that time, the aggregates that arise are like a scale, rising and falling. Therefore, it is not annihilated.
How is it not transferred?
Because sentient beings can be born in a place with the same type of aggregates from a place with a different type of aggregates. Therefore, it is not transferred.
How does it produce great fruits from small causes?
Creating small karma, receiving great ripening. Therefore, it produces great fruits from small causes.
Because the causes one creates lead to the corresponding effects, they are similar to each other.
Therefore, one should contemplate the Dharma of dependent origination in five ways.
Venerable ÅšÄriputra!

If there are people who can always contemplate with right wisdom the Dharma of dependent origination taught by the TathÄgata, which is without life, apart from life, of the nature of suchness, of the nature of non-erroneousness, unborn, unarisen, uncreated, unconditioned, unobstructed, without objects, tranquil, fearless, unassailable, inexhaustible, of the nature of non-tranquility, non-existent, empty, false, without substance, like a disease, like an ulcer, like an arrow, a fault, impermanent, suffering, empty, and without self,
whether I had birth in the past
or had no birth,
I do not discriminate the limit of the past.
In the future world, where will I be born? I also do not discriminate the limit of the future.
What is this?
What is this?
What is it made of?
Where do these sentient beings come from?
Where will they go after they cease to exist here?
They also do not discriminate the present existence.

They are also able to eliminate the various views of the world's Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, namely the view of self, the view of sentient beings, the view of longevity, the view of personhood, the view of rarity, the view of auspiciousness, and the view of opening and closing.
Because they are well understood.
Like a tÄla tree, they clearly uproot all afflictions and in the future will realize the Dharma of non-arising and non-cessation.
Venerable ÅšÄriputra!

If there are people who are endowed with such forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas and are well able to discern this principle of causes and conditions, the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the One Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, the Well-Gone One, the Knower of the Secular World, the Unexcelled Leader, the Trainer of Men, the Teacher of Gods and Men, the Buddha, the World-Honored One, will immediately bestow upon them the prediction of unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.

At that time, after Maitreya Bodhisattva MahÄsattva had spoken these words, ÅšÄriputra and all the devas, humans, asuras, gandharvas, and so forth in the world, having heard the Dharma taught by Maitreya Bodhisattva MahÄsattva, believed and accepted it in reverence.
The Buddha Speaks the SÅ«tra of the Great Vehicle's Rice Seedling
